# The Best Hotel Restaurants In DC

Whether you’re an overnight guest or just live down the street.

photo credit: Alhambra

[Madeline Weinfield](/contributor/madeline-weinfield)

Hotel restaurants often get overlooked in favor of other heavy-hitters, but writing them off in DC would be a major oversight. There are some seriously good restaurants hidden in the district’s hotels—great news if you’re visiting from out of town and feel like eating in, or a local looking for a change of pace. Here’s where to eat, whichever bucket you fall into.

###### What Our Ratings Mean

[Learn more](/ratings-explainer)

NONE

1-5

6s

7s

8s

9s

Unrated: This is a restaurant we want to re-visit before rating, or it’s a coffee shop, bar, or dessert shop. We only rate spots where you can eat a full meal.

## THE SPOTS

[## Dōgon](/washington-dc/reviews/dogon)

[1330 Maryland Ave SW, Washington, District of Columbia 20024](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=D%C5%8Dgon+1330 Maryland Ave SW, Washington, District of Columbia 20024)

$$$$

[Afro-Caribbean](/washington-dc/cuisines/afro-caribbean)

[Southwest Waterfront](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/southwest-waterfront)

Perfect For:[Special Occasions](/washington-dc/perfect-for/special-occasions)[Date Nights](/washington-dc/perfect-for/date-night)[Big Groups](/washington-dc/perfect-for/big-groups)[Impressing Out of Towners](/washington-dc/perfect-for/impressing-out-of-towners)

Name a DC restaurant that doesn’t have burrata and tuna crudo on their menu and you might come up empty. That’s reason enough to eat at Dōgon, the sleek, impossibly cool restaurant at the Salamander Hotel. Dōgon’s Afro-Caribbean menu is one of the most unique we’ve seen in the city—the hoe crab with plantain and the spiced-to-perfection roasted chicken with jollof rice is what we’ll be ordering on repeat. Come here with your hard-to-impress friends from out of town. The dishes are designed to share, generously portioned, decadently rich, and worth valet parking your car for.

[RESERVE A TABLE](https://resy.com/cities/washington-dc/venues/dogon-by-kwame-onwuachi)

Scott Suchman

9.4

[## The Bazaar](/washington-dc/reviews/the-bazaar)

[1100 Pennsylvania Ave NW, Washington, D.C. 20004](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=The%20Bazaar+1100 Pennsylvania Ave NW, Washington, D.C. 20004)

$$$$

[Spanish](/washington-dc/cuisines/spanish)

[Penn Quarter](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/penn-quarter)

Perfect For:[Birthdays](/washington-dc/perfect-for/birthdays)[Corporate Cards](/washington-dc/perfect-for/corporate-cards)

If you have a rich uncle visiting town, this is where you should take him. Located in what was the Waldorf-Astoria hotel, The Bazaar has a white tablecloth vibe and elevated takes on classics, like a deconstructed caesar salad and a pricey rendition of a Philly cheesesteak. It’s a José Andrés spot, so people come to see and be seen, for special occasions, or when someone else is picking up the tab. But more than any big-name guest, the real star of the show is the jamón Ibérico, which moves around the dining room on its own cart and is carved by hand tableside.

[RESERVE A TABLE](http://www.opentable.com/r/the-bazaar-by-jose-andres-dc-washington?ref=16825)

Rey Lopez

7.8

[## Michele’s](/washington-dc/reviews/micheles)

[1201 K St NW, Washington, D.C. 20005](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Michele%E2%80%99s+1201 K St NW, Washington, D.C. 20005)

$$$$

[French](/washington-dc/cuisines/french)

[Downtown](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/downtown)

Perfect For:[Night On The Town](/washington-dc/perfect-for/night-on-the-town)[Drinking Great Cocktails](/washington-dc/perfect-for/drinking-great-cocktails)[See & Be Seen](/washington-dc/perfect-for/see-and-be-seen)

Michele’s is perpetually bumping. The loosely French-inspired restaurant gets a visiting crowd thanks to its location in the Eaton DC, but it’s also popular with locals who otherwise come to the hotel for its co-working space and packed event schedule. We like to come here aftera meal for a round of cocktails before moving on to the Eaton’s speakeasy-style bar, Allegory.

[RESERVE A TABLE](https://www.opentable.com/r/micheles-washington?ref=16825)

Michele's

[## The Greenhouse](/washington-dc/reviews/the-greenhouse)

[1200 16th St NW, Washington, D.C. 20036](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=The%20Greenhouse+1200 16th St NW, Washington, D.C. 20036)

$$$$

[American](/washington-dc/cuisines/american)

[Downtown](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/downtown)

Perfect For:[Date Nights](/washington-dc/perfect-for/date-night)[Drinking Great Cocktails](/washington-dc/perfect-for/drinking-great-cocktails)[Impressing Out of Towners](/washington-dc/perfect-for/impressing-out-of-towners)[Fine Dining](/washington-dc/perfect-for/fine-dining)

Some dates call for a perfectly stirred martini, and those dates should be saved for dinner at The Greenhouse. While the Jefferson Hotel is popular with foreign dignitaries—some of whom might be eating at the table next to yours—the candlelight, historic fireplace, and tables cordoned off with curtains inspire more romance than business. Regardless of your reason for being here, you’ll want to dress up (your best blazer would fit in well). The menu is mostly fancy classics like scallops, oysters, and squid ink risotto, and while nothing’s revolutionary, everything is prepared exceptionally, and the white tablecloth, classic DC vibe justifies the price tag.

[RESERVE A TABLE](https://www.opentable.com/r/greenhouse-at-the-jefferson-washington-dc?ref=16825)

The Greenhouse

[## Café Riggs](/washington-dc/reviews/cafe-riggs)

[900 F St NW, Washington, D.C. 20004](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Caf%C3%A9%20Riggs+900 F St NW, Washington, D.C. 20004)

$$$$

[American](/washington-dc/cuisines/american)

[Penn Quarter](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/penn-quarter)

Perfect For:[Brunch](/washington-dc/perfect-for/brunch)[Coffee & A Light Bite](/washington-dc/perfect-for/coffee-a-light-bite)[Getting Work Done](/washington-dc/perfect-for/getting-work-done)

If hotel restaurants were entrants in a beauty pageant, Café Riggs would win the looks category hands down. This all-day-restaurant has architectural bones, a pastel palette, and soaring ceilings, and we love that the historic bank building (now the Riggs Hotel) retains its character with original teller windows and a bank vault. It all makes for a grand setting for a perfectly presented brunch with out-of-town guests. Café Riggs is also a stylish post-work spot, and great for a cocktail after a visit to the National Portrait Gallery across the street.

[RESERVE A TABLE](https://www.sevenrooms.com/reservations/caferiggs)

Café Riggs

[## Blue Duck Tavern](/washington-dc/reviews/blue-duck-tavern)

[1201 24th St NW, Washington, D.C. 20037](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Blue%20Duck%20Tavern+1201 24th St NW, Washington, D.C. 20037)

$$$$

[American](/washington-dc/cuisines/american)

[Georgetown](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/georgetown)

Perfect For:[Brunch](/washington-dc/perfect-for/brunch)[Date Nights](/washington-dc/perfect-for/date-night)[Fine Dining](/washington-dc/perfect-for/fine-dining)

At first glance, Blue Duck Tavern in the Grand Hyatt might look like the kind of place where serious deals are made over a few martinis. However, the quality of their menu is the real reason people come here—bring some dining companions who are impressed by steak, caviar, and bone marrow. Ordering a la carte is great for a quicker meal, but every now and then we like to go all the way with the ten course tasting menu. Ask for a table near the open kitchen, because watching the expert tweezer work of the chefs is excellent dinner theater.

[RESERVE A TABLE](https://www.exploretock.com/blueducktavern?utm_source=infatuation)

Blue Duck Tavern

[## Le Sel](/washington-dc/reviews/le-sel)

[1315 16th St NW, Washington, D.C. 20036](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Le%20Sel+1315 16th St NW, Washington, D.C. 20036)

$$$$

[French](/washington-dc/cuisines/french)

[Dupont Circle](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/dupont-circle)

Perfect For:[Brunch](/washington-dc/perfect-for/brunch)[Casual Dinners](/washington-dc/perfect-for/casual-dinners)[Walk-Ins](/washington-dc/perfect-for/walk-ins)

Finding a table for brunch in Dupont Circle without a reservation should be an Olympic Sport, and although we can’t guaranteeyou a coveted mid-morning seat, you have a pretty good chance of having a Bloody Mary in hand within a few minutes of walking into Le Sel. The Kimpton Banneker Hotel’s restaurant is a solidly reliable place to grab brunch when you haven’t made reservations or don’t feel like waiting a long time for a table. And don’t overthink it—French staples like pain perdu and croque monsieur with a side of frites is what it’s all about.

[RESERVE A TABLE](https://resy.com/cities/washington-dc/venues/le-sel)

[## No Goodbyes](/washington-dc/reviews/no-goodbyes)

[1770 Euclid St NW, Washington, D.C. 20009](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=No%20Goodbyes+1770 Euclid St NW, Washington, D.C. 20009)

$$$$

[American](/washington-dc/cuisines/american)

[Adams Morgan](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/adams-morgan)

Perfect For:[First Dates](/washington-dc/perfect-for/first-dates)[Drinks & A Light Bite](/washington-dc/perfect-for/drinks-a-light-bite)[People Watching](/washington-dc/perfect-for/people-watching)

You probably haven’t had a date in a church before, but there’s a first time for everything. This restaurant and bar at the Line Hotel was a church before it became an “it” spot in Adams Morgan. The people watching is great—not one baggy suit in sight—and the large original windows offer stunning views of the neighborhood. Grab a seat beneath the soaring vaulted arches and munch on small plates like raw local oysters, shoestring fries, and a pickled vegetable platter. Even if the date isn’t great, your cocktail and bar snacks will be.

[RESERVE A TABLE](https://www.opentable.com/r/no-goodbyes-washington?ref=16825)

No Goodbyes

[## Cut](/washington-dc/reviews/cut-dc)

[1050 31st St NW, Washington, DC 20007](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Cut+1050 31st St NW, Washington, DC 20007)

$$$$

[American](/washington-dc/cuisines/american)

[Georgetown](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/georgetown)

Perfect For:[Corporate Cards](/washington-dc/perfect-for/corporate-cards)[Special Occasions](/washington-dc/perfect-for/special-occasions)[Impressing Out of Towners](/washington-dc/perfect-for/impressing-out-of-towners)

DC loves its steakhouses, and perhaps nowhere does medium rare better than Cut, the Wolfgang Puck restaurant in the Rosewood Hotel. Cut feels like a movie version of a hotel steakhouse—sleek decor and low lighting complement the deal makers and dates, complete with clinking martini glasses and sharp knives slicing into expertly cooked cuts of filet mignon, wagyu, and rib eye. Don’t be discouraged if you’re dining with (or are yourself) a non-meat eater—Cut’s bluefin tuna tartare on crispy rice is satisfying enough to keep anyone coming back.

[RESERVE A TABLE](https://www.opentable.com/r/cut-by-wolfgang-puck-washington-district-of-columbia?ref=16825)

[## Alhambra](/washington-dc/reviews/alhambra)

[923 Black Lives Matter Plaza NW, Washington, District of Columbia 20006](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Alhambra+923 Black Lives Matter Plaza NW, Washington, District of Columbia 20006)

$$$$

[Mediterranean](/washington-dc/cuisines/mediterranean)

[Downtown](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/downtown)

Perfect For:[Date Nights](/washington-dc/perfect-for/date-night)[Corporate Cards](/washington-dc/perfect-for/corporate-cards)[People Watching](/washington-dc/perfect-for/people-watching)

The bar at the St. Regis Hotel is almost always crowded, yet the hotel’s restaurant, Alhambra, is rarely anywhere near full. We love coming here for a weekday dinner when the dining room feels ultra-intimate—there are even booths with curtains for added privacy. This is a place for trading state secrets or telling someone you love them over a menu of mostly small, shareable plates. Get the crab croquettes served with jamon serrano and the smoked eggplant mousse topped with dates and pomegranates, and end the meal with the tableside tiramisu.

[RESERVE A TABLE](https://www.opentable.com/r/alhambra-washington?ref=16825)

Alhambra

[## Estuary](/washington-dc/reviews/estuary-dc)

[950 New York Ave NW, Washington, D.C. 20001](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Estuary+950 New York Ave NW, Washington, D.C. 20001)

$$$$

[American](/washington-dc/cuisines/american)

[Penn Quarter](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/penn-quarter)

Perfect For:[Late Nights](/washington-dc/perfect-for/late-nights)[Night On The Town](/washington-dc/perfect-for/night-on-the-town)[Drinking Great Cocktails](/washington-dc/perfect-for/drinking-great-cocktails)[Drinks & A Light Bite](/washington-dc/perfect-for/drinks-a-light-bite)

The city somehow seems bigger than it actually is when looking through Estuary’s floor-to-ceiling glass windows. Maybe it’s because the restaurant, on a high floor of the Conrad Hotel, is itself massive, so much so that you’re practically guaranteed a seat anytime of night. But it’s a bar stool we come for, especially to begin or end a night downtown. Estuary walks the line between serving comforting late night (until 12am) snacks like chicken tenders and shrimp cocktail and elegant, DC-themed drinks. Get an Air and Space cocktail, a round of tenders, and look out at the city lights.

[RESERVE A TABLE](https://www.opentable.com/r/estuary-washington?ref=16825)

Estuary

## Written By

[#### Madeline Weinfield](/contributor/madeline-weinfield)

[DC](/washington-dc)Guide

# The Best Italian Restaurants In DC

Where to eat Italian in DC when you aren’t willing to settle.

photo credit: Nina Palazzolo

[Omnia Saed](/contributor/omnia-saed), [Allison Robicelli](/contributor/allison-robicelli) & [Mekita Rivas](/contributor/mekita-rivas)

DC has great Italian food. The historic Italian enclaves like [Adams Morgan](https://www.theinfatuation.com/washington-dc/guides/best-restaurants-bars-adams-morgan-dc) may have introduced the city to creamy risotto, juicy ragu, and coffee-soaked tiramisu, but you can find great Italian all around town—and this guide is here to prove it. Here are the chicken parms that inspire bipartisanship, spaghetti that saves relationships, and lasagnas that provide emotional support in times of need.

###### What Our Ratings Mean

[Learn more](/ratings-explainer)

7s

8s

9s

Unrated: This is a restaurant we want to re-visit before rating, or it’s a coffee shop, bar, or dessert shop. We only rate spots where you can eat a full meal.

## THE SPOTS

[## Ama](/washington-dc/reviews/ama)

[885 New Jersey Ave SE, Washington, DC 20003](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Ama+885 New Jersey Ave SE, Washington, DC 20003)

$$$$

[Northern Italian](/washington-dc/cuisines/northern-italian)

[Navy Yard](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/navy-yard)

Perfect For:[Special Occasions](/washington-dc/perfect-for/special-occasions)[Eating At The Bar](/washington-dc/perfect-for/eating-at-the-bar)[Walk-Ins](/washington-dc/perfect-for/walk-ins)[Date Nights](/washington-dc/perfect-for/date-night)

Ama means love in Italian, which is a great name for a place that is easily one of our favorite-date night spots in the city. The focaccia di formaggio for the table is an ideal icebreaker, with savory crescenza cheese that oozes out with each stretch of the bread. The fritto misto is an addictive medley of lightly fried anchovies, prawns, and calamari, topped with a zesty lemon squeeze, which tastes like summers spent hopping from one coastal Italian seafood shack to another (or so we’d imagine). If you’re inclined to recreate the spaghetti smooch from *Lady and the Tramp*, spring for the classic spaghetti al pomodoro.

[RESERVE A TABLE](https://resy.com/cities/washington-dc/venues/ama-dc)

Giada Paoloni

[## Centrolina](/washington-dc/reviews/centrolina-dc)

[974 Palmer Alley NW, Washington, D.C. 20001](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Centrolina+974 Palmer Alley NW, Washington, D.C. 20001)

$$$$

[Italian](/washington-dc/cuisines/italian)

[Downtown](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/downtown)

Perfect For:[Date Nights](/washington-dc/perfect-for/date-night)[Special Occasions](/washington-dc/perfect-for/special-occasions)[Impressing Out of Towners](/washington-dc/perfect-for/impressing-out-of-towners)

Smack dab in the hyperluxury of CityCenter, Centrolina delivers Italian cooking with enough polish to fit in with its well-heeled neighbors. With a fireplace and buttery light surrounded by lots of marble and right angles, it manages to feel luxurious yet welcoming. Come here dressed to the nines for a five-course dinner, or post up at the bar in your best blue jeans for a cocktail and focaccia so light it might float off the table. There’s lots of loveliness across the seasonally-rotating menu, like the roasted porcini mushrooms drenched in rosemary-infused butter broth, but the real reason to come to Centrolina are the pastas. Springy squid ink bucatini arrives coated in a lush tomato-eggplant ragu that demands you pause your dinner conversation, no matter how lively, in order to close your eyes and sigh contentedly.

[RESERVE A TABLE](http://www.opentable.com/r/centrolina?ref=16825)

Nina Palazzolo

[## Caruso’s Grocery](/washington-dc/reviews/carusos-grocery)

[914 14th St SE, Washington, District of Columbia 20003](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Caruso%E2%80%99s%20Grocery+914 14th St SE, Washington, District of Columbia 20003)

$$$$

[Italian](/washington-dc/cuisines/italian)

[Capitol Hill](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/capitol-hill)

Perfect For:[Dinner with the Parents](/washington-dc/perfect-for/dinner-with-the-parents)[Date Nights](/washington-dc/perfect-for/date-night)

Dining at this Italian restaurant in Capitol Hill feels like entering a world where bad days don’t exist. Diners are snugly packed into tomato-red cushioned booths, trading in the day's passive aggressive emails for zesty lemon-butter chicken piccata and rich and velvety blood orange crème brûlées. The restaurant is always bustling with regulars who know to book weeks in advance so as to not get stuck eating dinner at 9:30pm. But it doesn’t really matter when you eat—or what you eat, because each bowl of truffle butter alfredo and spicy seafood tagliatelle is here to remind you that while not every problem has a solution, pasta is always there to make it just a little better.

### How to get into Caruso’s Grocery

Reservations should be made at least three weeks in advance for prime-time tables during the week, and a month out for the weekend. They do accept walk-ins at the bar, but expect a wait.

[RESERVE A TABLE](http://www.opentable.com/r/carusos-grocery-dc-washington?ref=16825)

Nina Palazzolo

8.9

[## Piccolina](/washington-dc/reviews/piccolina)

[963 Palmer Alley NW, Washington, D.C. 20001](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Piccolina+963 Palmer Alley NW, Washington, D.C. 20001)

$$$$

[Italian](/washington-dc/cuisines/italian)

[Penn Quarter](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/penn-quarter)

Piccolina is a solid option for affordable Italian downtown, especially during the daytime. The espresso program is excellent, as are the bread and pastries, which are baked in-house in full view of the dining room. The all-day menu is ideal for sharing, with pizzas that come out of the wood-fired oven beautifully blistered without overly blackening, and sandwiches that can easily satiate the hangry with just a half. While it’s nice to enjoy Piccolina with company, we suggest keeping the sandwiches all to yourself, enjoying half right away and saving the rest for later, particularly the porchetta, which gets better as it sits.

Scott Suchman

[## Cucina Morini](/washington-dc/reviews/cucina-morini)

[901 Fourth St NW, Washington, District of Columbia 20001](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Cucina%20Morini+901 Fourth St NW, Washington, District of Columbia 20001)

$$$$

[Italian](/washington-dc/cuisines/italian)

[Mt. Vernon Triangle](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/mt-vernon-triangle)

Perfect For:[Breakfast](/washington-dc/perfect-for/breakfast)[Brunch](/washington-dc/perfect-for/brunch)[Happy Hours](/washington-dc/perfect-for/happy-hour)

Cucina Morini is run by the same chef behind [Caruso’s Grocery](https://www.theinfatuation.com/washington-dc/reviews/carusos-grocery). And while we thoroughly enjoy the new Mt. Vernon Triangle spot, its dinner menu won’t be dethroning Caruso’s anytime soon. But their breakfast? That’s where the magic happens. The sit-down dining room transforms into a light and airy café, and the evening’s fanciness gets tossed out the window. You pick a table, grab your own utensils, and scan a QR code to order. Make sure that includes a bunch of bread-based dishes, like the smoked salmon toast, the avocado sandwich, and at least one cornetto.

Cucina Morini

7.8

[## Osteria Al Volo](/washington-dc/reviews/osteria-al-volo)

[1790 Columbia Rd NW, Washington, DC 20009](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Osteria%20Al%20Volo+1790 Columbia Rd NW, Washington, DC 20009)

$$$$

[Italian](/washington-dc/cuisines/italian)

[Adams Morgan](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/adams-morgan)

Perfect For:[Casual Dinners](/washington-dc/perfect-for/casual-dinners)

Osteria Al Volo’s faded gray awning is easily overlooked, tucked beside a taqueria with the world’s largest and brightest neon sign. But make the effort to find it, because once you step inside, the smell of freshly baked bread, garlic, and olive oil will make the search worthwhile. The kitchen sits in the center of the room and acts like one giant diffuser, filling the space with the scent of endless short rib and ravioli. The cozy spot is great for laid-back hangouts, and the long wooden table in the back is ideal for large group get-togethers. The standing menu is full of classics like cacio e pepe and spaghetti carbonara, but it’s the restaurant’s weekly specials, like their saucy and tenderly braised duck ragu, that keep us coming back.

Osteria Al Volo

7.7

[## L’Ardente](/washington-dc/reviews/lardente)

[200 Massachusetts Ave NW, Washington, D.C. 20001](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=L%E2%80%99Ardente+200 Massachusetts Ave NW, Washington, D.C. 20001)

$$$$

[Italian](/washington-dc/cuisines/italian)

[East End](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/east-end)

Perfect For:[Special Occasions](/washington-dc/perfect-for/special-occasions)[Corporate Cards](/washington-dc/perfect-for/corporate-cards)[Date Nights](/washington-dc/perfect-for/date-night)[Impressing Out of Towners](/washington-dc/perfect-for/impressing-out-of-towners)

L’Ardente is one of DC’s poshest restaurants, so naturally, securing a reservation at the Italian spot in the East End is hard. But you won’t regret hunting on Resy two weeks in advance once you taste their 40-layer lasagna. Slide into a teal booth seat in the gold and white dining room with floor-to-very-high-ceiling windows, and order the buttery dish, rich in truffle and cheese, and full of tender short ribs. If lasagna’s not your thing, get the zucca: little bell pepper-shaped pasta served with a spicy sausage ragu with a generous meat-to-pasta ratio. Finish your evening with dessert—and the fire presentation that comes with the tiramisu. Don’t say we didn't warn you.

[RESERVE A TABLE](https://resy.com/cities/washington-dc/venues/lardente)

Nina Palazzolo

8.5

[## Fiola Mare](/washington-dc/reviews/fiola-mare)

[3050 K St NW, Washington, D.C. 20007](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Fiola%20Mare+3050 K St NW, Washington, D.C. 20007)

$$$$

[Seafood](/washington-dc/cuisines/seafood)

[Georgetown](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/georgetown)

Perfect For:[Date Nights](/washington-dc/perfect-for/date-night)[Dinner with the Parents](/washington-dc/perfect-for/dinner-with-the-parents)[Special Occasions](/washington-dc/perfect-for/special-occasions)

Fiola Mare is the type of place where people who own boats pull up for a quick dinner after a lap on the water. The outdoor patio hosts seats overlooking the Washington Harbour and it’s an incredibly fancy place, with plush carpet, a formal dress code, and a suited up staff. The menu is pricey, with cocktails averaging around $25, but the food is outstanding. Their crudos are the stars of the menu, and the oysters served with a strawberry mignonette are delightful. Get those and your meal will be off to a great start.

[RESERVE A TABLE](https://resy.com/cities/washington-dc/venues/fiola-mare)

Greg Powers

7.7

[## Gemini](/washington-dc/reviews/gemini-dc)

[1509 17th St NW, Washington, D.C. 20036](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Gemini+1509 17th St NW, Washington, D.C. 20036)

Gemini is a natural wine shop serving some of DC’s most exciting Italian food. If you want to sit down to eat, you’ll need to grab one of the small tables that occupy the former street parking spot out front—perfect for pizza night with the kids—which fill up almost immediately after it opens at 5pm. Pasta has to be eaten inside, where there are a few tall tables and counters but no seats. And while eating pasta in an upright position might not be comfortable, it’s worth it at Gemini. Made in-house and cooked just shy of al dente, they come cloaked in sauces that have been taken very, *very* seriously. There’s also an ice cream cart on the sidewalk, in case you’re not in the mood to enter a building at all. It’s an odd place with odd rules, which only adds to the magic.

Gemini

Trattoria Alberto is the one of the few things everyone on Capitol Hill can agree on. The old-school restaurant with its cherry wood furniture and white linen table cloths is usually full of senators and staffers not-so-quietly discussing cuts to healthcare access over piping hot plates of chicken parm. And while the present company might leave a bad taste in your mouth, the food, like their creamy pesto fettuccine, is done well. Their creme brûlée, which they keep simple with cream, vanilla, and sugar, is one of the best in the city.

It’s natural to wonder if some award-winning restaurants are worth the hype (and the price tag) but at Fiola, there’s no need for second guessing. Steps away from the Washington monument, the restaurant is decked out in white table cloths, gleaming silverware, and handwritten notes welcoming you to the table. The attention to detail creates the perfect setting for a [special occasion](https://www.theinfatuation.com/washington-dc/guides/best-dc-restaurants-special-occasions) or a dinner where you’re looking to impress. There are three [tasting menus](https://www.theinfatuation.com/washington-dc/guides/best-tasting-menus-dc), but the five-course Tradition is our go-to. Begin with a caviar and ricotta appetizer before moving onto the gnocchi al burro e formaggio, and end the night with the tartufo calabrese.

Filomena Ristorante has been serving DC pasta for 40 years, and you’ll be hard pressed to find a spot that does a better job. Which is probably why the [Georgetown](https://www.theinfatuation.com/washington-dc/guides/georgetown-restaurants) basement eatery is packed day and night, as folks turn everything from a [simple weeknight dinner](https://www.theinfatuation.com/washington-dc/guides/casual-weeknight-dinner-dc) to a milestone [birthday](https://www.theinfatuation.com/washington-dc/guides/best-birthday-dinner-dc) into an experience as big as Filomena’s chicken parmesan. The waiters are fresh to death in their tuxedos, while you try—and fail—to avoid dripping red sauce onto the white knit placemat under your ravioli. That mix of fancy and homey is what continues to make Filomena a spot where everyone comes to celebrate big moments, share fun nights with friends, or test their new elastic waist pants trying to down an entire plate of Pasta Mamma-made ravioli in one sitting.

[## Tonari](/washington-dc/reviews/tonari-dc)

[707 Sixth St NW, Washington, District of Columbia 20001](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Tonari+707 Sixth St NW, Washington, District of Columbia 20001)

[Italian](/washington-dc/cuisines/italian)

Just as America created its own distinctive interpretation of Italian food, so did Japan, and you can get a taste stateside at this lively Chinatown spot just across from the arena. The pasta dishes are built on noodles from a ramen maker in Japan and tossed in sauces that are traditionally Italian—the iconic Marcella Hazan tomato sauce has a home here, with a dollop of ricotta and a snow shower of pecorino and parm. In other dishes, the Italian sauces are remixed with Japanese ingredients. The vodka in vodka sauce gets swapped for sake, and white miso turns the umami of white clam sauce up to 11. The pizzas, too, are made with Japanese flour. The most popular is the Mentaiko Corn, which is slathered with sweet corn sauce and salty cod roe Kewpie mayo. It’s a fantastic bite to grab before the game.

If you live in Bloomingdale, count yourself lucky to call The Red Hen a neighborhood restaurant. Come here to catch up with friends over glasses of orange wine and crispy fried arancini—and soon enough, you'll be basking in the warm glow of the red brick room. The entrees, like slow-cooked beef cheek pappardelle, are delicious, and do that thing that good Italian food does which makes you feel like you’re eating at someone’s home. Just make sure y'all don't start feeling so comfortable that your friends start kicking off their shoes and undoing their belts. You’re still in public.

# The Best DC Restaurants For Date Night

Where to eat with someone who likes you back.

photo credit: Nina Palazzolo

[Tristiaña Hinton](/contributor/tristiana-hinton),  [Omnia Saed](/contributor/omnia-saed), [Madeline Weinfield](/contributor/madeline-weinfield) & [Thomas Rose](/contributor/tom-rose)

Finding someone who shares your passion for birdwatching can be hard, but picking a restaurant to swap photos of cerulean warblers doesn’t have to be. This is our guide to the best date night spots in DC, whether you’re planning a first date with someone you’ve only met digitally, nursing that year-long casual stage, or just want to spend some quality time with the person who splits your internet bill. If you're looking for something a little more adventurous, check out our guide to [DC’s most fun dinner spots](https://www.theinfatuation.com/washington-dc/guides/most-fun-dinner-spots-dc).

###### What Our Ratings Mean

[Learn more](/ratings-explainer)

Unrated: This is a restaurant we want to re-visit before rating, or it’s a coffee shop, bar, or dessert shop. We only rate spots where you can eat a full meal.

## THE SPOTS

[## Dōgon](/washington-dc/reviews/dogon)

[1330 Maryland Ave SW, Washington, District of Columbia 20024](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=D%C5%8Dgon+1330 Maryland Ave SW, Washington, District of Columbia 20024)

$$$$

[Afro-Caribbean](/washington-dc/cuisines/afro-caribbean)

Perfect For:[Special Occasions](/washington-dc/perfect-for/special-occasions)[Date Nights](/washington-dc/perfect-for/date-night)[Big Groups](/washington-dc/perfect-for/big-groups)[Impressing Out of Towners](/washington-dc/perfect-for/impressing-out-of-towners)

If you want to have date night at Dōgon, you’re going to need to plan well in advance (and prove your commitment by setting a bunch of reservation notifys). The newest restaurant from Kwame Onwuachi is tucked in the lobby of the Salamander hotel on the Southwest Waterfront, and it’s as romantic as it gets. Soft R&B plays in the background, and large pillars give way to little intimate nooks where you and your significant other can split plates of smoky, charred wagyu short rib and some tangy BBQ greens.

### How to get into Dōgon

Reservations are tough to secure, even weeks in advance, but you can score a walk-in seat and full menu service at the compact bar for up to two guests in a party. Get there early to have a fighting chance.

Albi, a Middle Eastern restaurant in [Navy Yard](https://www.theinfatuation.com/washington-dc/guides/nats-park-navy-yard-restaurants-bars), is the place to take your date when you really need to prove you know how to plan a fun evening. The $195 tasting is served with piping hot pita that might be the best in the city, and if they give you the lettuce wraps with the carrot and tuna pastes, savor the crispy, flavorful goodness. Reservations open a month in advance, and that's when you should book if you want to avoid the early bird 5pm dinner slot. Albi does offer walk-in seating at the bar, but you’ll miss all the action in the dining room and open kitchen.

On any given night at this French bistro-ish prix fixe spot, you might eat corn ravioli with truffles and tarragon foam while listening to Will Smith’s “Wild Wild West.” Or, if you’re lucky, you’ll get a Nutter Butter-shaped “PB&J” made with foie gras instead of peanut butter while sipping on a gin and honey cocktail served in a sculptural stainless steel bee. This is all to say that Bresca is fun, and the sort of place that's just as suited to celebrating anniversaries that end in a "0" as it is an impromptu date night. From the complimentary chamomile kombucha when you walk in to the housemade gummy bear that closes out the meal, there’s a reason that after nearly ten years this place is still a go-to date night spot.

[1522 Wisconsin Ave NW, Washington, DC 20007](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Lut%C3%A8ce+1522 Wisconsin Ave NW, Washington, DC 20007)

Looking for a low-key date night that wraps up by 10pm? Lutèce, a quaint neo-bistro in [Georgetown](https://www.theinfatuation.com/washington-dc/guides/georgetown-restaurants), is the move. Try a few different things by going a la carte, or let the chef take the wheel via the $125 tasting menu, with an optional $75 wine pairing. Speaking of, Lutèce has a great wine list, and if your date loves the syrah they’re drinking, be extra thoughtful by getting them a subscription to the restaurant’s wine club. It’s a way smoother move than the standard “Had a great time tonight!” text.

### How to get into Lutèce

Be open to a table on the patio. Yes, Wisconsin Avenue is a main artery of Georgetown and it will be loud—and less charming than inside—but the food and wine will be just as memorable. Prime dinner time reservations for the dining room tend to fill up several weeks out, so plan in advance. The Chef’s Table, with a $125 tasting menu, is slightly easier to book.

(H)ours at Manifest 002 stands against every broad stroke misconception of DC. Instead of cold concrete and brutalist angles, its lilac cushions and soft edges. Instead of imported politicians in poorly tailored suits, it’s homegrown hustlers in Margiela jackets. And instead of traditional steakhouse fare, it’s contemporary soul food fused with flavors from around the world: think tuna crudo meets chow-chow and bolognese shakes hands with Ethiopian spice. All together, (H)ours is a great spot for a third or fourth date if you're looking for something that's delicious but a little more buttoned-down than the typical DC steakhouse. If a love letter existed in restaurant form, it would look like Ama. Providencia, from the team behind [Maketto](https://www.theinfatuation.com/washington-dc/reviews/maketto), combines Salvadorian, Dominican, and Taiwanese flavors in a tiny space about the size of the H Street trolley. Here, the cocktails are called “memories” and paired with poetic epithets, tea candles flicker underneath exposed wood beams, and a wall of triangle breeze blocks sits behind the bar. On paper, this might sound pretentious. In reality, Providencia is a lively neighborhood spot serving some of the city’s best cocktails and the most inventive bar food on H Street—and maybe all of DC. We’d say save Providencia for special occasions, but the prices are so reasonable it's great even for a casual Tuesday date night. Come for a drink and a light bite, but whatever you do don't miss their baked alaska. It’s good enough to cross town for on the coldest night in February.

[RESERVE A TABLE](https://resy.com/cities/washington-dc/venues/providencia)

Melanie Landsman

# The Hit List: New DC Restaurants To Try Right Now

Your guide to the best new restaurants in Chocolate City.

photo credit: Eunoia

[Madeline Weinfield](/contributor/madeline-weinfield), [Jonathan Smith](/contributor/jonathan-smith), [Allison Robicelli](/contributor/allison-robicelli) & [Thomas Rose](/contributor/tom-rose)

When new restaurants open, we check them out. This means that we subject our stomachs and social lives to the good, the bad, and more often than not, the perfectly fine. And every once in a while, a new spot makes us feel like Kamala Harris at a pantsuit sale. When that happens, we add it here, to The Hit List.

The Hit List is where you’ll find all of the best new restaurants in DC**.** As long as it opened within the past several months and we’re still talking about it, it’s on this guide.The latest addition might be a buzzy new restaurant with caviar priced by the bump. Or it might be an under-the-radar lunch counter where a few dollars will get something that’ll rattle around in your brain like a loose penny in a dryer.

Keep tabs on the Hit List and you will always know just which new restaurants you should be eating at right now.

**New to the Hit List (12/11): Eunoia**

[## Eunoia](/washington-dc/reviews/eunoia)

[320 Florida Ave NE, Washington, District of Columbia 20002](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Eunoia+320 Florida Ave NE, Washington, District of Columbia 20002)

$$$$

[Fusion](/washington-dc/cuisines/fusion)

[Dupont Circle](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/dupont-circle)

Perfect For:[Date Nights](/washington-dc/perfect-for/date-night)[Unique Dining Experiences](/washington-dc/perfect-for/unique-dining-experience)

At first glance, nothing about Eunoia makes a lot of sense. The menu, which leans heavily into Mexican cuisine (tacos and mole are stars), steers without warning into Bulgarian and Japanese flavors, with some phyllo dough here and some miso paste there. The upscale [Union Market](https://www.theinfatuation.com/washington-dc/guides/best-dishes-union-market) space seems to be more straightforward, playing into the industrial-chic nature of the building, with high ceilings, glass walls, and exposed pipes. But then, as if taking a cue from the menu, the unexpected comes into view: Eunoia isn’t just a restaurant, it’s also a Pilates studio. It is, admittedly, a bit weird. But the food—the improbable mashup of three unrelated cuisines—lands. So much so that we’re willing to look past the bare feet crossing our sightline mid-bite.

[RESERVE A TABLE](https://resy.com/cities/washington-dc/venues/eunoia-restaurant)

Eunoia

[## Eebee’s Corner Bar](/washington-dc/reviews/eebees-corner-bar)

[1840 Sixth St NW, Washington, District of Columbia 20001](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Eebee%E2%80%99s%20Corner%20Bar+1840 Sixth St NW, Washington, District of Columbia 20001)

$$$$

The debut venture from the beer director behind [Green Zone](https://www.theinfatuation.com/washington-dc/reviews/the-green-zone) and the ever-expanding Andy’s Pizza empire, Eebee’s caters to off-shift industry workers with a kitchen that’s open until 2am. It's a bar first and foremost, but the food is no afterthought. Options include a turkey club, shrimp cocktail, and some of the best mozzarella sticks we’ve ever had, thinly breaded with almost no grease. There’s also a $25 burger with a perfectly seasoned, nearly two-inch-thick patty. The place hits capacity early and stays that way through most weekend nights, but even on school nights most bar seats are filled by off-shift hospitality workers. Order a martini and the onion rings or club sandwich and strike up a conversation with a stranger. If they end up becoming your emergency contact, nobody will be surprised—this place was designed for a meet-cute.

Thomas Rose

[## Maison Bar À Vins](/washington-dc/reviews/maison-bar-a-vins)

[1834 Columbia Rd NW, Washington, District of Columbia 20009](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Maison%20Bar%20%C3%80%20Vins+1834 Columbia Rd NW, Washington, District of Columbia 20009)

The latest jewel box of a restaurant from the team behind [Lutéce](https://www.theinfatuation.com/washington-dc/reviews/lutece) and [Pascual](https://www.theinfatuation.com/washington-dc/reviews/pascual)—people who seem constitutionally incapable of getting it wrong—sits in a former [Adams Morgan](https://www.theinfatuation.com/washington-dc/guides/best-restaurants-bars-adams-morgan-dc) row home that spent three decades as the Cuban nightclub Habana Village. Anyone who appreciates Lutèce and Pascal’s penchant for biodynamic wines will find plenty to love here, with a list that runs over a thousand vintages long. But while Maison Bar à Vins bills itself as a wine bar, the food alone is worth a visit. The smoked eel croquettes, exceptionally creamy and topped with a thin sliver of singed eel, are a standout. For something more substantial, the brioche stuffed chicken is theoretically big enough to share, but the crunchy brioche and buttery chanterelle mushrooms could turn the most communal-minded diner into a food hoarder.

(H)ours At Manifest 002 bucks DC stereotypes. Instead of cold concrete and brutalist angles, its lilac cushions and soft edges. Instead of imported politicians in poorly tailored suits, it’s homegrown hustlers in Margiela jackets. And instead of traditional steakhouse fare, it’s contemporary soul food fused with flavors from around the world. The restaurant is attached to a members club that also includes a barber shop, cafe, retail store, and more. Just like the building it’s in, the food here isn’t content to be simply one thing. Butter for the bread is also a lit candle. Signature cocktails include an aromatic bowl of tea. And the dishes pair flavors from opposite sides of the globe. At (H)ours, tuna crudo meets chow-chow and bolognese shakes hands with Ethiopian spice.

Karravaan in [Union Market](https://www.theinfatuation.com/washington-dc/guides/best-dishes-union-market) feels like it’s been here for a hundred years. The restaurant channels the sleek glamor of a 1920s Beirut café crossed with a waiting room for the Orient Express, with tiled floors, bentwood chairs, an oversized clock, and a wall of windows that seems perfect for watching an approaching train. That mishmash of design choices makes sense in a restaurant whose menu traces the Silk Road, serving up dishes like falafel topped with slivered ginger, khachapuri filled with steaming goat feta, and lamb sliders with sumac and jalapenos. Za’atar fries are a natural companion, as are the cocktails, like the mezcal and pét-nat Bedouin Sunset, which is mixed with lime bitters and blood orange syrup.

A downtown DC favorite until it closed in late 2024, Sushi Gaku has resurfaced in [Georgetown](https://www.theinfatuation.com/washington-dc/guides/georgetown-restaurants) with a new address and a new look. Yes, you can still splurge on the $180 omakase, but the à la carte menu makes it just as easy to have a good time. The first thing you should do at Café Fiorello is order a martini. Not only will it be perfectly chilled and shaken with just enough olive brine to keep things interesting, but it will arrive at your table on a silver tray and delicately placed on the white tablecloth by a server who seems like they’ve been training their whole life for this moment. The Italian American restaurant has been a [New York City institution](https://www.theinfatuation.com/new-york/reviews/cafe-fiorello) since 1974, and the DC outpost has captured the spirit of the original. It’s easy to get swept up in the beauty of Fiorello’s pastas (their peppery spaghetti carbonara is shockingly rich, and exactly what we crave on a cold evening). But the eggplant parmesan is the star of the menu. Their version takes up an entire dinner plate, and while this is a dish that usually makes us want to go take a nap, Fiorello’s version is lighter thanks to the fact that the eggplant is baked rather than breaded and fried.

[3210 Cherry Hill Ln NW, Washington, District of Columbia 20007](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=My%20Little%20Chamomile%20+3210 Cherry Hill Ln NW, Washington, District of Columbia 20007)

My Little Chamomile is a Turkish restaurant from the team behind [Green Almond Pantry](https://www.theinfatuation.com/washington-dc/reviews/green-almond-pantry). Tucked down a quaint [Georgetown](https://www.theinfatuation.com/washington-dc/guides/georgetown-restaurants) alley, the quiet dining room is a place you can bring your parents, your professor, or anyone you need to whisper a secret to without having to shout across the table. The vegetable-forward menu works best shared, and the smallish portions make it easy to skip around. If tomatoes are still in season, start with the super fresh coban salatası. Otherwise, the girit ezmesi, an overload of feta, labneh, and goat cheese whipped together and dusted with pistachios, or the dedemin biberi, anaheim peppers marinated in vinegar and garlic with just enough kick to make them interesting, both make great ice breakers. For something more substantial, we love the mantı beef dumplings with yogurt. Finish with chamomile tea (naturally) and the tel kadayıf, a dessert that recalls baklava but uses shredded phyllo.

We’re a little confused as to why the second location of Fish Shop opened in DC (the original is in the Scottish countryside town of Ballater, pop. 1400) but we’re not complaining. Opened by the folks at Artfarm, the hospitality arm of the global gallery Hauser & Wirth, the sweeping 180-seat seafood spot takes some inspiration from the gallery, with a massive installation of floating fish sculpted from North Carolina wisteria and Scottish willow. While Fish Shop's roots are Scottish, its menu is decidedly mid-Atlantic, built around what’s fresh from the Chesapeake Bay, Rappahannock River, Atlantic Ocean, and local farms. Think small bites like Maryland crab crumpets and New Jersey squid, as well as hearty mains like Maryland blue crab conchiglie and grilled New Jersey mackerel. There is nothing subtle about Chai Pani in Union Market. The 4,000 square-foot space sits under a canopy of bright pink bougainvilleas and orange garlands, and a mini market complete with a photogenic pani puri cart sells spices, cookbooks, and other branded merch. But underneath the splashy space, Chai Pani is serving some of the best [Indian food](https://www.theinfatuation.com/washington-dc/guides/best-indian-restaurants-dc) in DC. You can go alone, but we wouldn’t recommend it. Come with a crew and order a spread of chaat like the excellent kale pakora, with a batter so light and crispy you’ll swear they found a way to deep-fry air, or the puri with potato, onion, and sweet yogurt. The Sloppy Jai, made with spiced lamb, green chutney, and sweet yogurt, is a staple of the restaurant's original location in [Asheville](https://www.theinfatuation.com/asheville/reviews/chai-pani-asheville), and it’s served here as two small pav sliders, ideal for sharing. Chai Pani knows how to play the hits, too. The methi malai paneer is rich with cashew cream and cardamom, and a nice anchor for a lot of the small plates that should be flying around your table.

Elmina is what happens when Ghanaian food shows up to DC’s fine dining scene in its Sunday best. The $135 four-course tasting menu blends deep tradition with sharp technique: think scallop crudo with citrus and coconut, rich palm nut stew with shrimp and octopus, and a jollof duck pot dripping with smoky, pepper-laced shito. The obvious move at Elmina, from celebrity chef Eric Adjepong, is to come for a birthday, anniversary, or some other occasion that warrants a nice shirt and planning ahead. And while it’s great for that, we also love to come here on a whim and sit at the bar for the more casual a la carte menu, where you can get bites like okra fries, octopus kebabs with a shito glaze, or a hamachi collar with plantain chips.

Eighteen years after Nancy Silverton opened [Osteria Mozza](https://www.theinfatuation.com/los-angeles/reviews/osteria-mozza) in LA, the iconic Italian restaurant has arrived in [Georgetown](https://www.theinfatuation.com/washington-dc/guides/georgetown-restaurants). It doesn’t matter why or when you find yourself underneath the dining room’s soaring ceilings, eating at Osteria Mozza feels like an occasion. Start with the Focaccia di Recco. It’s not an option so much as a necessity—an ultra-thin, crispy, cheese-stuffed marvel finished with some of the best olive oil we’ve ever tasted. The sea trout is pan-seared to crisp-skinned perfection, its buttery flesh offset by the acidity of braised red cabbage, earthy Roveja peas, and the surprising richness of hard-boiled eggs. But if we had to pick just one reason to visit Osteria Mozza, it would be the dessert menu. The tiramisu is outstanding, but playing favorites feels unfair. If you decided to skip dinner entirely and focus solely on desserts, we wouldn’t judge you. In fact, we might join you.

[## The Occidental](/washington-dc/reviews/the-occidental)

[1475 Pennsylvania Ave NW, Washington, District of Columbia 20004](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=The%20Occidental+1475 Pennsylvania Ave NW, Washington, District of Columbia 20004)

$$$$

[American](/washington-dc/cuisines/american)

[Downtown](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/downtown)

Originally opened in 1906 a stone’s throw from the White House, generations of presidents, senators, and journalists have flocked to The Occidental to make history, or drink their way out of it. Now, after a century of grandeur interspersed with bouts of irrelevance, Stephen Starr has stepped in and dusted off the red velvet. The midcentury menu revives dishes that haven’t been on-trend since the Eisenhower administration, and does them so spectacularly you’ll wonder how exactly they went out of style in the first place. You’ll find the requisite raw bar with oysters and cold king crab legs, but also a nod to Soviet dining in the herring under a fur coat. There’s caviar and crab cakes, of course, but also pigs in a blanket, made from Hebrew National hot dogs wrapped in the Occidental’s soon-to-be-legendary biscuits. The Occidental is a loving homage—and an assertive return—to power dining with a wink and a flourish, where you can eat like a Kennedy and drink like a Cold War diplomat.

[RESERVE A TABLE](https://resy.com/cities/washington-dc/venues/the-occidental)

Birch Thomas

# 13 Classic Restaurants In DC

Eating in DC just wouldn’t be the same without these spots.

photo credit: Old Ebbitt Grill

[Omnia Saed](/contributor/omnia-saed) & [Tristiaña Hinton](/contributor/tristiana-hinton)

The thing that pushes a restaurant into "classic" territory is often intangible. It's not just about longevity or good food—a lot of classics are endearingly imperfect. They can have great oysters but bad lighting, average half-smokes and an amazing history. No, something as special as a classic restaurant needs more than a lengthy relationship with the utilities company. At its most basic, a true institution should make youfeel some connection to the city you can't get in other places. If it can do that, well, then, that's what makes it a stone-cold classic. These are DC’s best.

## THE SPOTS

[## The Monocle](/washington-dc/reviews/the-monocle)

[107 D St NE, Washington, D.C. 20002](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=The%20Monocle+107 D St NE, Washington, D.C. 20002)

[Steakhouse](/washington-dc/cuisines/steakhouse)

A steakhouse is as much a DC institution as traffic cameras, questionable politicians, and Fannie Mae. The Monocle on Capitol Hill is not only one of the city’s oldest, it’s undeniably [one of its best](https://www.theinfatuation.com/washington-dc/guides/best-steakhouses-dc). Sit at the small wooden bar if you want to hear Hill staffers spilling congressional secrets after one too many ginger Manhattans.

[## Old Ebbitt Grill](/washington-dc/reviews/old-ebbitt-grill)

[675 15th St NW, Washington, D.C. 20005](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Old%20Ebbitt%20Grill+675 15th St NW, Washington, D.C. 20005)

$$$$

[American](/washington-dc/cuisines/american)

[Downtown](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/downtown)

Perfect For:[Classic Establishment](/washington-dc/perfect-for/classic-establishment)[Casual Dinners](/washington-dc/perfect-for/casual-dinners)[Dinner with the Parents](/washington-dc/perfect-for/dinner-with-the-parents)

Old Ebbitt Grill is one of DC’s most storied saloons, packed with old-school charm and still drawing crowds today, over 150 years after its opening in 1856. It’s moved around a bit over the years and the exact original location is a mystery, but what’s clear is its longstanding VIP appeal—President McKinley was such a fan he reportedly lived there during his Congressional days. Presidents Grant, Johnson, Cleveland, and Roosevelt all stopped in, basically making it the Studio 54 of 19th- and 20th-century Washington. Go for classic American fare like sirloin steaks, New England clam chowder, and chicken and waffles.

Old Ebbitt Grill

[## Murry & Paul’s](/washington-dc/reviews/murry-and-pauls)

[3513 12th St NE, Washington, D.C. 20017](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Murry%20%26%20Paul%E2%80%99s+3513 12th St NE, Washington, D.C. 20017)

$$$$

[Diner](/washington-dc/cuisines/diner)

[Brookland](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/brookland)

Perfect For:[Breakfast](/washington-dc/perfect-for/breakfast)[Walk-Ins](/washington-dc/perfect-for/walk-ins)[Serious Takeout Operation](/washington-dc/perfect-for/serious-take-out-operation)

Murry & Paul’s is a real-deal old-school diner. Not one of the new spots cosplaying as authentic that we see pop up in DC from time to time, but the if-you-don’t-know-your-order-head-to-the-back-of-the-line type joint. A faded menu hangs on the wall, where plates are stacked against brown linoleum walls and squeeze bottles of hot sauce stand on every table. It’s one of DC’s few remaining cash-only restaurants, where you can still get $7 omelets and $8 breakfast specials.

Nina Palazzolo

7.7

[## Rasika](/washington-dc/reviews/rasika)

[633 D St NW, Washington, D.C. 20004](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Rasika+633 D St NW, Washington, D.C. 20004)

$$$$

[Indian](/washington-dc/cuisines/indian)

[Penn Quarter](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/penn-quarter)

Perfect For:[Lunch](/washington-dc/perfect-for/lunch)[Date Nights](/washington-dc/perfect-for/date-night)[Special Occasions](/washington-dc/perfect-for/special-occasions)[Big Groups](/washington-dc/perfect-for/big-groups)

Rasika in Penn Quarter has been open since 2005 and is part of a local empire that now includes a West End location, [Bindaas](https://www.theinfatuation.com/washington-dc/reviews/bindaas), and The Bombay Club, which first introduced Indian fine dining to the city. When you make it here and taste the crispy baby spinach and sweet chutney of their palak chaat, or the crab pepper masala with a delicate pastry covering, it’ll be clear that 20 years after it opened Rasika is still serving some of the best food in the district.

[RESERVE A TABLE](https://resy.com/cities/washington-dc/venues/rasika)

Nina Palazzolo

9.2

[## Heat Da Spot](/washington-dc/reviews/heat-da-spot)

[3213 Georgia Ave NW, Washington, DC 20010](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Heat%20Da%20Spot+3213 Georgia Ave NW, Washington, DC 20010)

$$$$

[Ethiopian](/washington-dc/cuisines/ethiopian)

[Petworth](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/petworth)

Perfect For:[Breakfast](/washington-dc/perfect-for/breakfast)

At Heat Da Spot, you get the best of both worlds: [breakfast](https://www.theinfatuation.com/washington-dc/guides/great-breakfast-dc) and Ethiopian food. The Petworth cafe is a Monday morning rite of passage for commuters filling up on their Zoom essentials: caramel iced cinnamon honey lattes, berbere-spiced scrambled eggs, and chechebsa, a flatbread marinated in spiced butter. If it’s your first time, start with a BEC, Heat Da Spot’s classic breakfast sandwich with the perfect cheese-to-bacon-to-egg ratio. Sprinkle on some berbere peppers, and it might just quickly become your favorite breakfast sandwich in the city.

Nina Palazzolo

[## Florida Avenue Grill](/washington-dc/reviews/florida-avenue-grill)

[1100 Florida Ave NW, Washington, D.C. 20009](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Florida%20Avenue%20Grill+1100 Florida Ave NW, Washington, D.C. 20009)

$$$$

[Diner](/washington-dc/cuisines/diner)

Perfect For:[Breakfast](/washington-dc/perfect-for/breakfast)[Classic Establishment](/washington-dc/perfect-for/classic-establishment)[Walk-Ins](/washington-dc/perfect-for/walk-ins)

Florida Avenue Grill has been a DC institution since 1944. It’s an old-school diner, so think tattered vinyl booths and bar seats that have withstood the test of time, with customers that range from longtime regulars to the occasional tourist. Their world-famous hot cakes, served with butter, cinnamon, and powdered sugar, are the stuff of dreams—they’re light, fluffy, buttery, and sweet. Things take time here and the service can be slow, but as the saying goes, good things come to those who wait.

Jai Williams

7.8

[## Annie’s Paramount Steak House](/washington-dc/reviews/annies-paramount-steak-house)

[1609 17th St NW, Washington, DC 20009](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Annie%E2%80%99s%20Paramount%20Steak%20House+1609 17th St NW, Washington, DC 20009)

$$$$

[Steakhouse](/washington-dc/cuisines/steakhouse)

[Dupont Circle](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/dupont-circle)

Perfect For:[Casual Dinners](/washington-dc/perfect-for/casual-dinners)[Classic Establishment](/washington-dc/perfect-for/classic-establishment)[Big Groups](/washington-dc/perfect-for/big-groups)

For over 75 years, Annie’s has been a refuge for DC’s LGBTQ+ community, where the words “you don’t have to hide that here” can be found on laminated placards on every table. The family-owned steakhouse in Dupont Circle keeps it casual with a bartender shouting from behind the bar, inviting you to sit wherever you want, and a “formal dining” room brimming with laid-back groups in sneakers, jeans, and polyester pants (because the best way to eat a steak is in loungewear). Regulars know their go-to dishes among the Maryland crab cakes and grilled ribeye steak—for us, that includes an order of the sweet and sour key-lime pie with extra whipped cream.

Nina Palazzolo

7.4

[## Tabard Inn & Restaurant](/washington-dc/reviews/tabard-inn)

[1739 N St. NW, Washington, D.C. 20036](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Tabard%20Inn%20%26%20Restaurant+1739 N St. NW, Washington, D.C. 20036)

You never know who you’ll run into at the Tabard Inn & Restaurant. An old colleague? An old flame? Your grad school professor? The over 100-year-old establishment is an in-the-know revolving door for DC, and even though it’s located in well-trodden Dupont Circle, chances are whoever you bring here didn’t even know this place existed. A wood-burning fireplace, live jazz on Sunday and Monday nights, and cozy, low-slung ceilings make this a great place to come for a cocktail while half listening to the music, half listening to the person you’re with.

[## El Tamarindo](/washington-dc/reviews/el-tamarindo)

[1785 Florida Ave NW, Washington, D.C. 20009](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=El%20Tamarindo+1785 Florida Ave NW, Washington, D.C. 20009)

$$$$

[Salvadoran](/washington-dc/cuisines/salvadoran)

Perfect For:[Casual Dinners](/washington-dc/perfect-for/casual-dinners)[Happy Hours](/washington-dc/perfect-for/happy-hour)

DC’s largest immigrant population hails from El Salvador, and that means there are lots of fantastic places to get Salvadoran classics. El Tamarindo in [Adams Morgan](https://www.theinfatuation.com/washington-dc/guides/best-restaurants-bars-adams-morgan-dc) is our oldest Salvadoran spot, and serves up fast, flavorful food. The menu is a mix of Salvadoran and Mexican, so along with pupusas, sweet plantains, and tamales, there are tacos, burritos, and fajitas. It’s a casual spot that gets busy with both visitors and locals, and there’s an all-day Happy Hour at the bar if you have some free time.

[RESERVE A TABLE](https://www.exploretock.com/eltamarindodc?utm_source=infatuation)

[1213 U St NW, Washington, D.C. 20009](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Ben%E2%80%99s%20Chili%20Bowl+1213 U St NW, Washington, D.C. 20009)

The most famous [Black-owned restaurant in DC](https://www.theinfatuation.com/washington-dc/guides/black-owned-restaurants-washington-dc) might not make the most memorable food in the city, but we never pass up the chance to grab a half-smoke at Ben’s Chili Bowl anyways. Inside, you can scan through the photos of visitors from across the decades scattered around the restaurant that tell the history of both Ben’s and “Black Broadway.” Prepare to wait in line to get some food, which you can eat at the counter or, if you’re lucky, at one of the few red booths. Get the original chili half-smoke with all the fixings, and make sure you ask them to split it.

Reema Desai

7.4

[## Jaleo](/washington-dc/reviews/jaleo)

[480 7th St NW, Washington, D.C. 20004](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Jaleo+480 7th St NW, Washington, D.C. 20004)

José Andrés is the unofficial culinary king of DC, and Jaleo is his crown jewel. The Spanish restaurant in Penn Quarter has been open since the ‘90s, and although the food falls squarely in the “just fine” category, the restaurant’s location and huge dining room that’s [great for a last-minute group dinner](https://www.theinfatuation.com/new-york/guides/last-minute-group-dining-nyc) make it a popular choice. With over 50 tapas to choose from, dining here can sometimes feel like an old-school game of Battleship. There are definitely some misses, but every once in a while, you come across a hit.

[## Tony Cheng’s Seafood Restaurant](/washington-dc/reviews/tony-chengs)

[619 H St NW, Washington, D.C. 20001](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Tony%20Cheng%E2%80%99s%20Seafood%20Restaurant%20+619 H St NW, Washington, D.C. 20001)

$$$$

[Chinese](/washington-dc/cuisines/chinese)

[Chinatown](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/chinatown)

Perfect For:[Classic Establishment](/washington-dc/perfect-for/classic-establishment)

Like the Washington Monument or the US Capitol building, Tony Cheng’s is a spot you want to see when you walk down H St. It’s a living monument, a testament to what [Chinatown](https://www.theinfatuation.com/washington-dc/guides/best-chinese-restaurants-chinatown-dc) used to be, even if the menu can be a little hit-or-miss. And the restaurant’s tenure is obvious—the felt seats probably haven’t been upholsftered since it opened in the ’80s, and the walls with photos of Jimmy Carter and Marion Berry feel more like a historical shrine than decor. Stick to ordering the seafood, like the slightly sweet black garlic scallop and shrimp and the crispy crab wontons, which are a firework of flavor.

Reema Desai

[## Filomena Ristorante](/washington-dc/reviews/filomena-ristorante)

[1063 Wisconsin Ave NW, Washington, D.C. 20007](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Filomena%20Ristorante+1063 Wisconsin Ave NW, Washington, D.C. 20007)

$$$$

[Italian](/washington-dc/cuisines/italian)

Perfect For:[Classic Establishment](/washington-dc/perfect-for/classic-establishment)[Date Nights](/washington-dc/perfect-for/date-night)[Dinner with the Parents](/washington-dc/perfect-for/dinner-with-the-parents)

This [Georgetown](https://www.theinfatuation.com/washington-dc/guides/georgetown-restaurants) restaurant has been serving DC pasta for over 40 years, and you’ll be hard-pressed to find [a spot that does a better job](https://www.theinfatuation.com/washington-dc/guides/best-italian-restaurants-dc). The underground dining room is packed day and night, as folks turn everything from simple weeknight dinners to birthdays into an experience as big as Filomena’s chicken parm. There’s a homey feel to the place, filled with antique knickknacks that look like they’ve been acquired throughout the last century. And that coziness, combined with the giant plates, is what keeps huge groups coming back night in and night out.

[RESERVE A TABLE](http://www.opentable.com/filomena-ristorante?ref=16825)

Nina Palazzolo
